Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Fate and Consequences of Yakutat Terrane Subduction Beneath Eastern Alaska and the Wrangell Volcanic Field
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Summary

The Wrangell Volcanic Field is one of the largest outpourings of volcanic rocks on the planet in the past 2.6 million years, but its relationship to processes of plate tectonics remains enigmatic. Locations of earthquakes underneath Alaska indicate that the Pacific plate is sliding beneath Alaska in a process of subduction. These earthquakes stop abruptly west of the Wrangell mountains, but somehow the plates continue to converge for several hundred kilometers eastward through the Wrangell region. Because of the close connections between subduction and mountain building, the south Alaska region provides an exceptional testing ground to test theories of how the mantle behaves when slabs end, and how convergence makes earthquakes in subduction zones.

The centerpiece of this study is a temporary network of 37 broadband seismic stations deployed across southern Alaska to complement the EarthScope Transportable Array network along critical transects. It is providing data to tell whether or not subduction occurs under the Wrangells, and how the Alaska-Aleutian subduction zone ends. The research is being performed by a team with a well-established collaborative track record in advancing our understanding of subduction zones by deploying seismic arrays and integrating their results with other observations and models. Ongoing collaborations with petrologists and geodynamicists are helping spread the results to a broader geoscience audience. The project supports the training and professional development of two graduate students and provides excellent field-based opportunities to engage undergraduates in research. Outreach programs at the University of Alaska Fairbanks provide structured links to schools and science education centers in the region, reaching native populations with cutting-edge research. It supports an interdisciplinary collaboration with ample opportunity for the continued cross-disciplinary education among researchers and students. The Wrangell Volcanic Field represents a significant contributor to the total eruptive record in North America, and this study will provide critical framework for understanding this hazard as well.

Technical Description

The proposed research is aiding significantly in improving our understanding of the dynamics of subduction zones, the response of lithosphere to subduction of buoyant crust, mass conservation in slab contortions, and the drivers of arc volcanism. Results from the temporary deployment of 37 broadband seismic stations focus on determining slab surface and wedge geometry from receiver functions in addition to ambient noise tomography, velocity and attenuation imaging, tremor and seismicity studies, and measuring anisotropy from shear wave splitting. It addresses the following questions: 1) Where is the eastern end of the Alaska-Aleutian slab, and what is its configuration? Does it end as a tear, or is it continuously warped? 2) What is the relationship between Yakutat crust subduction, transtension, and volcanism in the Wrangell mountains? Does regular subduction drive Wrangell volcanism, or flow and high temperatures at a tear or edge? Does thick Yakutat terrane crust subduct continuously beneath the Wrangell mountains? 3) What is the flow around the end of the Aleutian slab and how much is it driven by subduction versus larger plate-scale flow? Results are being used to understand the fate of subducted material beneath Alaska and its role in driving volcanism  and tectonics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Wrangell Volcanic Field (WVF) is one of the largest geologically recent outpourings of volcanic rocks on the planet, but its relationship to plate-tectonic processes remains enigmatic. It lies east of the obvious Alaska-Aleutian subduction zone, where the Pacific plate slides beneath Alaska and creates the Aleutian volcanic arc. It also lies west of the large Queen Charlotte-Fairweather transform fault system that defines the North America-Pacific plate boundary in the Alaska Panhandle and northern British Columbia region. To resolve the origins of this major but poorly studied feature, a 36-station temporary seismic array was deployed in 2016-18. It complements the EarthScope Transportable Array deployment, a major community facility covering Alaska for several years to greatly enhance scientific investigation, along critical transects.

 

Data from the combined arrays have been used in a variety of studies to better understand earthquakes and earth structure in the region, resolving the drivers of the volcanic field. One study uses these signals to detect tens of thousands of micro-earthquakes in the region, providing for the first time clear evidence for a dipping, deep slab of seismicity descending beneath the WVF from the Gulf of Alaska coast. This slab of seismicity, while oddly feeble, greatly resembles the pattern of earthquakes found at most other subduction zones on the planet. A second study investigates the effectiveness of wave propagation around the area, quantified as seismic attenuation or absorption of energy in seismic waves. Here too the pattern reveals clear similarities to subduction zones elsewhere, with very efficient propagation where the seismicity zone is shallow and a cold plate is descending, and very high attenuation or weak propagation beneath and behind the volcanic field where hot, perhaps molten mantle overlies the subducting plate. In a third study, signals have been mapped that come from reflections and mode conversions off the downgoing plate to better define it. A mode conversion occurs where seismic P waves hit a sharp interface and some of the energy converts to S-mode waves; the two kinds of waves can be isolated and because they travel at different speeds their observation provides information about depth and sharpness of interfaces. These signals confirm a clear subducting crust that is subducting to at least depths of 100 km. The crust resembles the large oceanic Yakutat plateau just off the south coast of Alaska, and is likely showing its subduction. These signals also map out the large fault near the coast at shallower depths, revealing a much more widespread, continuous fault zone than thought previously.  Finally, the fabric of mantle rocks has been mapped by distortions of seismic S waves – they are split into two waves traveling at different speeds due to the fabric. This mapping reveals the flow patterns associated with the Wrangell slab. All of these studies have been led by graduate students at Cornell and University of Alaska Fairbanks, forming some or all of their theses. Overall, these studies confirm the subduction nature of this small but voluminous volcanic field, and reaffirm the importance of subduction processes in generating a large fraction of the planet’s continental volcanoes.

 


Last Modified: 08/24/2021
Modified by: Geoffrey A Abers

To resolve the origins of this major but poorly studied feature, a 36-station temporary seismic array was deployed in 2016-18. It complements the EarthScope Transportable Array deployment, a major community facility covering Alaska for several years to greatly enhance scientific investigation, along critical transects. Data from the combined arrays have been used in a variety of studies to better understand earthquakes and earth structure in the region, resolving the drivers of the volcanic field. One study uses these signals to detect tens of thousands of micro-earthquakes in the region, providing for the first time clear evidence for a dipping, deep slab of seismicity descending beneath the WVF from the Gulf of Alaska coast. These signals confirm a clear subducting crust that is subducting to at least depths of 100 km. Finally, the fabric of mantle rocks has been mapped by distortions of seismic S waves – they are split into two waves traveling at different speeds due to the fabric. This mapping reveals the flow patterns associated with the Wrangell slab. All of these studies have been led by graduate students at Cornell and University of Alaska Fairbanks, forming some or all of their theses. Overall, these studies confirm the subduction nature of this small but voluminous volcanic field, and reaffirm the importance of subduction processes in generating a large fraction of the planet’s continental volcanoes.
